'
This phrase is a blatant admission of James''s style of writing. His narrator is flat-out telling us that fiction to him is just another way of drawing or painting, but with words instead of pencils or brush strokes. James''s writing is very visual and the narrator of Portrait will always be offering intricate descriptions of houses, gardens, and individual rooms in a way that reveals Henry James''s artistic philosophy. This philosophy is one that puts emphasis on the craft of writing and the painstaking care that goes into creating a fictional world like the one in which Isabel Archer and the Touchetts live. This narrator will make no attempt to remain invisible; you will always be aware that there is someone above these characters making art out of their lives.
'
quote: 'his eyes upon the rich red

text:
'Countess Gemini presents herself as a figure of knowledge here, elevated above Miss Stackpole in that she has seen the world of marriage from the other side. She has seen through the veneer of manners and of an institution that presents itself to the world as sacred, but is not always upheld as sacred by its participants. The contrast between knowledge and naivete here parallels the difference between Isabel''s former self in Volume I and the woman she has become after such a bitter and unfulfilling nuptial match.
'
quote: '"It''s\r\ncertain all the nice men do it. Get married and you''ll see!" she added.

text:
'This line numbers among the most significant in the text, as it shows Isabel finally acknowledging what has happened to her. She finally gets that she has been used and although she seems to be too deep into her awful marriage to leave, she at least knows who is a friend and who is an enemy in this novel. She is recognizing that the world is populated by many kinds of people, and one of those kinds is the Madame Merle type--the type of person who treats everything as a means to an end, even other people. Merle is punished for using Isabel and treating her like an object, but even so, Isabel realizes that Merle will continue to do the same thing to others: "She will make a convenience of America." The bleak reality is that Merle''s life will not change nearly as dramatically because of Isabel''s actions, but Isabel''s life has been destroyed by Merle''s.
'
quote: '"She made a convenience of me."

text:
'Though not choosing specifically to be miserable, Isabel here is choosing to leave her life open to some kind of grand suffering--perhaps in the belief that only with grand suffering can one achieve grand pleasure and love in one''s life, that there is some "extraordinary" thing waiting for her so long as she does not try to avoid the sufferings of life.
'
quote: '"From life. From the usual chances and dangers, from what most people know and suffer."  /

text:
'A great first sentence, giving the reader a full introduction into the world of the narration. It is, of course, a deceptive introduction: the story in question is not the main narrative in "The Turn of the Screw," but the preceding story, one that will be one-upped by what follows. James is giving the standard elements of the cliche "ghost story" (old houses, cold winter evenings, unnatural visitations), and even providing one simple twist (the child) before launching on his psychological reinvention of the genre.

This beginning also offers the nameless narrator that blurs the distinction between reality and fiction (the original readers might have wondered whether the I was James himself) and the framing device of a storytelling group ("us") going back to the earliest forms of oral and written literature (cf. campfire stories, Chaucer''s Canterbury Tales). A similar framing device is also present in another famous "horror" novella of the period, Joseph Conrad''s "Heart of Darkness."
'
quote: 'The story had held us, round the fire, sufficiently breathless, but except the obvious remark that it was gruesome, as, on Christmas Eve in an old house, a strange tale should essentially be, I remember no comment uttered till somebody happened to say that it was the only case he had met in which such a visitation had fallen on a child.

text:
'This "Douglas" is introduced matter-of-factly, providing at once the appearance of familiarity between the reader and the storytelling group and a layer of curiousity-inducing mystery.
'
quote: 'Douglas--not

text:
'Douglas in engaging in the peculiarly English practice later defined by Stephen Potter as "one-upmanship." Defined as "the systematic and conscious practice of making one''s associates feel inferior and thereby gaining the status of being ''one-up'' on them," one-upmanship was explored by Potter in a series of very amusing books in the mid-20th century, starting with "Gamesmanship" (1947). The film "School for Scoundrels" (1960, remade in the US in 2006) is based on Potter''s ideas.

The odd glee in Douglas'' comment about screw-turning (highlighted by the novella''s title) and his ambiguous use of the adjective "charming," are a first indication of the subtle undercurrent of Jamesian humor that permeates this ostensibly grim story.
'
quote: '"I quite agree--in regard to Griffin''s ghost, or whatever it was-- that its appearing first to the little boy, at so tender an age, adds a particular touch. But it''s not the first occurrence of its charming kind that I know to have involved a child. If the child gives the effect another turn of the screw, what do you say to TWO children--?"

text:
'Douglas'' "quiet art" is the kind of hammy melodramatic performance much enjoyed in the 1890s. By the time he wrote "The Turn of the Screw," James had spent many years attempting to establish himself in the lucrative world of the London theatre. He had not been successful in this endeavor and resented the more bombastic personalities who had. Douglas as a self-promoting, almost ridiculously effective storyteller resembles and Oscar Wilde character as much as he resembles Wilde himself.
'
quote: 'I can see Douglas there before the fire, to which he had got up to present his back, looking down at his interlocutor with his hands in his pockets. "Nobody but me, till now, has ever heard. It''s quite too horrible." This, naturally, was declared by several voices to give the thing the utmost price, and our friend, with quiet art, prepared his triumph by turning his eyes over the rest of us and going on: "It''s beyond everything. Nothing at all that I know touches it."

text:
'More subtle comedy, this time directed to enthusiasts of precisely the kind of "horror" tales that James is reinventing with "The Turn of the Screw." The 1890s witnessed a revival of the Gothic forms of the previous century, epitomized by the unstoppable success of Bram Stoker''s "Dracula." When James has Douglas gleefully advertise the "uncanny ugliness, horror and pain" of the story he''s about to tell, he''s gently mocking the very serious claims of masters of the macabre like Stoker or Arthur Machen (and later his more famous American pupil, H P Lovecraft). James'' own attitude to horror as a genre is closer to Jane Austen''s (in "Northanger Abbey"), or even Oscar Wilde''s in the more satirical parts of "The Portrait of Dorian Gray."
'
quote: '"For general uncanny ugliness and horror and pain."

text:
'James is having fun with another cliche of the gothic horror story: the concealed document locked for years in a secret container. A very famous example of this device is the amazing Polish novel "Manuscript Found in Saragossa" by Jan Potocki (made into a great 1960s film in Poland). Nathaniel Hawthorne used the device in the framing narrative ("The Custom House") to "The Scarlet Letter."
'
quote: '"The story''s written. It''s in a locked drawer-- it has not been out for years. I could write to my man and enclose the key; he could send down the packet as he finds it."

text:
'James inserts the first hint of ambiguity that has characterized the reception of the novella: it could be a ghost, or it could be anything else.
'
quote: 'agree--in regard to Griffin''s ghost, or whatever it was--

text:
'The narrator who, perhaps delusionally, imagines himself having a "special" relationship with a more important character is a typical Jamesian touch. His enchantment with Douglas echoes the governess'' pathetic crush on her employer in the main narrative.

It has been suggested that the "I" is female. James uses clearly female first person narrators elsewhere, but in this case he chose to leave the gender ambiguoous. Decades ago, the female narrator theory was buttressed by passages such as this one that implied a level of flirtation (imagined or not) between the narrator and Douglas. A queer reading, however, is not too far-fetched: the notoriously celibate James was known to flirt ambiguously with both men and women in his personal correspondence.
'
quote: 'It was to me in particular that he appeared to propound this-- appeared almost to appeal for aid not to hesitate. He had broken a thickness of ice, the formation of many a winter; had had his reasons for a long silence. The others resented postponement, but it was just his scruples that charmed me.

text:
'One of the functions of framing devices (particularly in hard-to-believe narratives like ghost stories) is to ground the main narrative within the scope of realism. This is a characteristic also well-known in the development of urban legends, which typically happened to a friend of a friend of the teller. This device establishes a chain of trust between the hearer and the improbable story. Here the narrator is charmed by Douglas, who has in turn clear affection for his governess who was the protagonist (and principal witness) of the story.
'
quote: '"Is in old, faded ink, and in the most beautiful hand." He hung fire again. "A woman''s. She has been dead these twenty years. She sent me the pages in question before she died." They were all listening now, and of course there was somebody to be arch, or at any rate to draw the inference. But if he put the inference by without a smile it was also without irritation. "She was a most charming person, but she was ten years older than I. She was my sister''s governess," he quietly said. "She was the most agreeable woman I''ve ever known in her position; she would have been worthy of any whatever. It was long ago, and this episode was long before. I was at Trinity, and I found her at home on my coming down the second summer. I was much there that year--it was a beautiful one; and we had, in her off-hours, some strolls and talks in the garden-- talks in which she struck me as awfully clever and nice. Oh yes; don''t grin: I liked her extremely and am glad to this day to think she liked me, too. If she hadn''t she wouldn''t have told me. She had never told anyone. It wasn''t simply that she said so, but that I knew she hadn''t. I was sure; I could see. You''ll easily judge why when you hear."

text:
'A way to distance the present of the frame (the Christmas season, presumably in the late 1890s, when the story was published) from two distant pasts--the narrator''s childhood and his older governess'' youth.
'
quote: 'It was long ago, and this episode was long before.

text:
'The reverse image to the cliche setting of the first sentence. James is preparing the ground for his unique take on the horror tropes.
'
quote: 'I remember the time and the place--the corner of the lawn, the shade of the great beeches and the long, hot summer afternoon.

text:
'A charming breach of the fourth wall, where Douglas (standing in for James, with encouragement from the besotted narrator) makes the case for sophisticated, subtle storytelling in the face of readers who crave cheap thrills and gossip. At this point in his career a frustrated (but always proud) James was reduced to making a meagre living writing for mass-market publications like "Collier''s Weekly," where "The Turn of the Screw" was first serialized.
'
quote: '"Who was it she was in love with?" "The story will tell," I took upon myself to reply. "Oh, I can''t wait for the story!" "The story WON''T tell," said Douglas; "not in any literal, vulgar way." "More''s the pity, then. That''s the only way I ever understand."

text:
'A tip of the hat to the earlier gothic tales and another reminder that the group is spending the Christmas holidays in a old house. By 1898, candlelight was steadily giving way to gas and electric illumination--the horror revival of the late 19th century was explcitly concerned with the irruption of modernity (with electricity, transportation, and communications as most visible signs)  and the "ghostly" reaction of the past. This is very clearly seen in "Dracula," a novel obsessed with new technologies and their application in defeating a monster made of feudal ruins, irrational lust, and superstition.
'
quote: 'And quickly catching up a candlestick, he left us slightly bewildered.

text:
'A metatextual moment: this is not "like" the mere opening of a serial--it is (as originally published in "Collier''s Weekly" magazine) the opening of a serial!

[In contemporary TV writing this trope is known as "Lampshade Hanging" (or "lampshading"). Tvtropes.org defines it as "Pointing out the use of a trope. Often used when a writer tries to excuse or explain a plot element that''s unlikely or overused by drawing attention to it. Also known as "hanging a clock on it", "hanging a lantern on it", or "spotlighting it." E.g., having a character say "This idea is so crazy, it just might work!" or "I feel like I''m in a badly written TV show.""]'
quote: 'The last story, however incomplete and like the mere opening of a serial, had been told;

text:
'More mediation of texts, achieving at the same time a reality-effect (the transmission history of the text is plausibly acknowledged and guaranteed by the narrator as authority) and opening the endless poissibilities of corruption, addition, suppression, or interpolation.

What James does here (as Cervantes does repeatedly throughout "Don Quixote") is giving the illusion of historicity to a fantastic tale (the ghost story in his case, the chivalric romance in Cervantes''). It''s the narrative polar opposite to the "once upon a time" of fairytales.
'
quote: 'Let me say here distinctly, to have done with it, that this narrative, from an exact transcript of my own made much later, is what I shall presently give. Poor Douglas, before his death--when it was in sight--committed to me the manuscript that reached him on the third of these days and that, on the same spot, with immense effect, he began to read to our hushed little circle on the night of the fourth.

text:
'Finally, the main narrative begins. In fact, this sentence could easily have been the first sentence of a socially realistic tale (like a Balzac story, for example). Everything that precedes it is carefully orchestrated by James to prepare the reader for his unique experiment.
'
quote: 'the youngest of several daughters of a poor country parson, had, at the age of twenty, on taking service for the first time in the schoolroom, come up to London, in trepidation, to answer in person an advertisement that had already placed her in brief correspondence with the advertiser.

text:
'This brief aside puts the chronology of the tale into further perspective. It turns out now that "1898" is not the present for the story and that the Christmas storytelling which opens it is already in the past. By this clever telescopic effect, James sends the main narrative even further into the haze of the distant past.
'
quote: 'Poor Douglas, before his death--when it was in sight--committed

text:
'James continues "hanging lampshades" (see above) and playing with the cliches and tropes of this kind o narrative. To the governess, her employer is like a character out of a novel, but this is also a wink to the reader and allows James to use shorthand to describe him. On a less artful writer this lampshading could be a sign of laziness. James, however, uses the trope to deceive the reader into taking the governess'' point of view as his or her own.
'
quote: 'This person proved, on her presenting herself, for judgment, at a house in Harley Street, that impressed her as vast and imposing--this prospective patron proved a gentleman, a bachelor in the prime of life, such a figure as had never risen, save in a dream or an old novel, before a fluttered, anxious girl out of a Hampshire vicarage.

text:
'Notice the almost imperceptible shift in point of view: the nameless narrator and Douglas have now vanished and we''re looking through the eyes of the governess.
'
quote: 'One could easily fix his type; it never, happily, dies out. He was handsome and bold and pleasant, offhand and gay and kind. He struck her, inevitably, as gallant and splendid, but what took her most of all and gave her the courage she afterward showed was that he put the whole thing to her as a kind of favor, an obligation he should gratefully incur. She conceived him as rich, but as fearfully extravagant-- saw him all in a glow of high fashion, of good looks, of expensive habits, of charming ways with women.

text:
'A small but crucial detail. The brief irruption of "India" in the story serves the dual purpose of linking the tale with the gothic tradition (heavy in exotic and "Oriental" motifs) and with the 19th century reality of the British empire (already introduced in the emplyer''s "big house filled with the spoils of travel and the trophies of the chase"). Though deceptively set in an almost ridiculously stereotypical English setting, the entire plot of "The Turn of the Screw" is triggered by a mysterious double death on the other side of the world.
'
quote: 'the death of their parents in India,

text:
'Another very subtle change in point of view. This is the enthralled governess parroting the language (and excuses) of her selfish employer. (Or, more accurately, the narrator parroting Douglas parroting the governess parroting the employer, a peculiar chain in which each mouthpiece is "charmed" by the previous storyteller!)
'
quote: 'These children were, by the strangest of chances for a man in his position--a lone man without the right sort of experience or a grain of patience--very heavily on his hands. It had all been a great worry and, on his own part doubtless, a series of blunders, but he immensely pitied the poor chicks and had done all he could; had in particular sent them down to his other house, the proper place for them being of course the country, and kept them there, from the first, with the best people he could find to look after them, parting even with his own servants to wait on them and going down himself, whenever he might, to see how they were doing. The awkward thing was that they had practically no other relations and that his own affairs took up all his time.

text:
'Mrs. Grose is in charge "below stairs only," that is, in charge of the maintenance of the house by a team of working class servants. The distinction between "downstairs" (working class service) and "upstairs" (the world of the wealthy and/or educated  property owners  and members of the household)  is anxiously noted by the socially conscious narrators.

The distinction gave name to a popular British TV series of the 1970s ("Upstairs, Downstairs," set in a townhouse in the early 20th century). Recent depictions of this form of rigurous social segregation (both critical in different ways) are the films "Remains of the Day" and "Gosford Park."
'
quote: 'but below stairs only--an

text:
'In the division between Upstairs and Downstairs, those in charge of the education of children existed in a kind of grey area. The employer is charming the governess by implying that she''ll have "supreme authority," but she in fact doesn''t: her authority derives entirely from him.

James choice of the governess as the main character in The Turn of the Screw is central to his relentless exploration of ambiguity in the story. Governesses were by definition ambiguous characters in the rigid social hierarchy of 19th century and early 20th century England.

Many years earlier, Charlotte Bronte explored a similar type of character feeling similar social dislocation in her novel "Villette" (1853).
'
quote: 'There were plenty of people to help, but of course the young lady who should go down as governess would be in supreme authority.

text:
'The previous governess is introduced in passing through the eyes of the employer. The first thing the reader knows about her is that "she was a most respectable person," a characterization that will be challenged by the ghost story.
'
quote: 'There had been for the two children at first a young lady whom they had had the misfortune to lose. She had done for them quite beautifully--she was a most respectable person-- till her death, the great awkwardness of which had, precisely, left no alternative but the school for little Miles.

text:
'The word "respectable" is repeated twice on this paragraph. This is the employer''s pitch to the governess and the emphasis on this word is meant to highlight it. What is and isn''t respectable is at the center of the governess'' psychology and thus of the ghost story itself.
'
quote: 'likewise thoroughly respectable.

text:
'A funny Jamesian aside breaking the fourth wall. After the repetition of the previous paragraph, a reader is meant to notice an emphasis on "respectability," but James plays with that recognition by jumping off the page and pointing out that there''s nothing particularly clever in notiing what he just did (i.e., even the crass joker interrupting Douglas gets it!).
'
quote: '"And what did the former governess die of?--of so much respectability?"

text:
'Dont'' forget that "The Turn of the Screw" was conceived for serialization. Here James is explicitly playing with the most basic device to build up suspense. "The Turn of the Screw" is paced like a serial, cliffhangers and all.
'
quote: '"She did wish to learn, and she did learn. You shall hear tomorrow what she learned.

text:
'James foregrounds the alternative explanation to the "ghost story" angle Douglas has been peddling since the beginning.
'
quote: '"The moral of which was of course the seduction exercised by the splendid young man. She succumbed to it."

text:
'The employer is shown as selfish and callous, thought the enthralled governess can''t see this. The "condition" is the cause of the girl''s total isolation and one of the triggers of the "ghost story."
'
quote: 'his main condition." "Which was--?" "That she should never trouble him--but never, never: neither appeal nor complain nor write about anything; only meet all questions herself, receive all moneys from his solicitor, take the whole thing over and let him alone.

text:
'Another almost metafictional moment, where the strange "I" is brought closer to James, who, of course, titled the story "The Turn of the Screw."
'
quote: '"What is your title?" "I haven''t one." "Oh, I have!"

text:
'One of the keys of James'' mastery of the psychological novel is the subtle description of how different people ascribe different meanings to the most simple acts. This is a beautiful example: a mere handshake is seen by the employer as a way to manipulate and impress a young social inferior, by the governess as an almost mystical marriage, by Douglas as a confirmation of the moral superiority and sense of sacrifice of his old friend, and by his skeptical listeners as a combination of all of the above.
'
quote: 'when, for a moment, disburdened, delighted, he held her hand, thanking her for the sacrifice, she already felt rewarded."

text:
'Withe this metaphor we are immediately placed within the emotional rollercoaster of the easily impressionable provincial young woman.
'
quote: 'a little seesaw

text:
'Of course the governess is not the mistress (the owner''s wife) or an important visitor. The "as if" continues her delusional fantasy of social advance that had begun during her interview.
'
quote: 'there immediately appeared at the door, with a little girl in her hand, a civil person who dropped me as decent a curtsy as if I had been the mistress or a distinguished visitor.

text:
'More delusional wishful thinking, though in this case with the irony that the "something beyond his promise" also could describe the ghost story that follows.
'
quote: 'suggested that what I was to enjoy might be something beyond his promise.

text:
'The governess'' belief in "on the spot" judgements about people''s characters from reading her appearance also limits her understanding of the complex reality of what had happened in the house before her arrival. Unlikely as it might seem to her, the "ghost story" provides a better explanation than coping with a challenge to her prejudiced views.
'
quote: 'The little girl who accompanied Mrs. Grose appeared to me on the spot a creature so charming as to make it a great fortune to have to do with her.

text:
'The governess again thinks she''s a keen reader of people, when in fact she is merely shallow and her characterizations are rushed and stereotypical.
'
quote: 'I perceived within half an hour that she was so glad--stout, simple, plain, clean, wholesome woman-- as to be positively on her guard against showing it too much.

text:
'"Angelic beauty" is a metaphor here, but coming from a parson''s daughter there''s also the more literal allusion that this upper-class beautiful child cannot be anything other than an angel. Within hours of meeting her, the governess has decided that "there could be no uneasiness" about the child.
'
quote: 'there could be no uneasiness in a connection with anything so beatific as the radiant image of my little girl, the vision of whose angelic beauty

text:
'The child''s name, far from being "angelic," points back to the pagan goddess of natural fertility.
'
quote: 'Flora

text:
'Now James is going overboard with the "angelic" characterization of Flora.
'
quote: 'with the deep, sweet serenity indeed of one of Raphael''s holy infants,

text:
'The governess thinks that herself and Mrs. Grose are the ones with secrets and roundabout allusions that the children wouldn'' understand.
'
quote: 'There were naturally things that in Flora''s presence could pass between us only as prodigious and gratified looks, obscure and roundabout allusions.

text:
'Typical "impersonal" phrasing characteristic of self-conscious middle-class, by-the-rules thinking usually mocked by both working-class straight-talkers and privileged libertines.
'
quote: 'One wouldn''t flatter a child.

text:
'"Carried away" here for the governess means "being pleasantly surprised" and "charmed." For the reader (and for other characters in the story) it also carries the subconscious connotations of forbidden social mobility (the Cinderella story, literally "carried away" from her modest upbringing by a prince) and also sexual abandon (being removed, taken, made to forget herself).
'
quote: '"You WILL be carried away by the little gentleman!" "Well, that, I think, is what I came for--to be carried away. I''m afraid, however," I remember feeling the impulse to add, "I''m rather easily carried away. I was carried away in London!"

text:
'She''s deluding herself: she clearly has.
'
quote: 'I''ve no pretension," I could laugh, "to being the only one.

text:
'The 19th century social structure in England was transitioning between the privilege of landed property and the privilege of capitalism that would triumph in the 20th century. Since the gothic horror story points to the vanishing past, and also since the imagination of the governess is both religious (angels/devils) and fabulous (princes from fairy tales), the nameless employer is denoted by his house. Harley Street is the employer in the same way the Bly is the "young gentleman" (or Henry V is "England" in Shakespeare''s plays).
'
quote: '"In Harley Street?" "In Harley Street."

text:
'The governess is insufferably patronizing to the working-class housekeeper. It makes for an interesting mental exercise to imagine "The Turn of the Screw" told from Mrs. Grose point of view.
'
quote: 'I somehow took her manner as a kind of comforting pledge--never falsified, thank heaven!--that we should on every question be quite at one. Oh, she was glad I was there!

text:
'Flora belongs to a class bred for "confidence and courage," the two things the governess has been educated to lack. Her surprise shows her lack of sophistication and exposure to those that were then called "her social betters."
'
quote: 'Young as she was, I was struck, throughout our little tour, with her confidence and courage

text:
'Although she tries to suppress the feeling by fantasizing about her situation, the governess is mentally (and almost physically) oppressed by her surroundings. She''s out of her depth.
'
quote: 'They had, as it were, an extent and mass for which I had not been prepared and in the presence of which I found myself, freshly, a little scared as well as a little proud.

text:
'Is James making a blunder in tone? Would the governess know the meaning of "machicolated"? James couldn''t resist showing off his knowledge of medieval architecture, but the word seems out of character for her. (A machicolation is "a floor opening between the supporting corbels of a battlement, through which stones and lethally hot liquids could be dropped on attackers at the base of a defensive wall.") 
'
quote: 'an old machicolated square tower

text:
'A more explicit description of the fabulous mental world of the governess at the time the story took place.

Later, however, older an wiser, she assesses the house in a different light. Still, the house she describes (except for the hyperrealistic "convenient") is the perfect gothic setting: a functional building partly in ruins, containing the "ghosts" of an earlier past that refuses to go away completely.
'
quote: 'I had the view of a castle of romance inhabited by a rosy sprite, such a place as would somehow, for diversion of the young idea, take all color out of storybooks and fairytales. Wasn''t it just a storybook over which I had fallen adoze and adream? No; it was a big, ugly, antique, but convenient house, embodying a few features of a building still older, half-replaced and half-utilized, in which I had the fancy of our being almost as lost as a handful of passengers in a great drifting ship. Well, I was, strangely, at the helm!

text:
'Yes, the uncle is a jerk.
'
quote: '"This, I recognize, is from the headmaster, and the headmaster''s an awful bore. Read him, please; deal with him; but mind you don''t report. Not a word. I''m off!"

text:
'The moral universe of this parson''s daughter is very simplistic. Here we see the opposite of Flora''s "angelic" demeanor. After the headmaster''s letter she starts being worried that Miles could be bad.
'
quote: '"Is he really BAD?"

text:
'The limited imagination of the governess conceals an overactive fantasy life. But because she was educated with the insecurities of the middle-class, constantly terrified both of failing to impress the privileged and of being lumped with the working-class, she is unable to voice many of her deepest thoughts. What can and cannot be named is at the center of the events of "The Turn of The Screw," before and after her arrival to Bly.

In the mid-20th century the phenomenon of middle-class anxiety about language was studied by Alan Ross and popularized by essayist Nancy Mitford. They used the expressions "U and non-U language" to refer respesctively to genuine upper-class usage vs. delusional middle-class usage that was caused by their misguided attempt to appear educated to the upper-class. What they noticed was that, for example,  while both a U-speaker and also a working-class person would say "napkin," a non-U speaker would anxiously say "serviette" to appear more cultured.

In "The Turn of the Screw," the governess is clearly a non-U speaker, while her employer and the children are U-speakers. This linguistic difference affects her narrative and her interpretation of actions and events.
'
quote: 'That can have only one meaning." Mrs. Grose listened with dumb emotion; she forbore to ask me what this meaning might be; so that, presently, to put the thing with some coherence and with the mere aid of her presence to my own mind, I went on: "That he''s an injury to the others."

text:
'More patronizing of Mrs. Grose.
'
quote: 'with one of the quick turns of simple folk,

text:
'Here Mrs. Grose is proving to be as supersticious and superficial as the governess. The glamour of aristocratic children immediately prejudices them in their favor. Any wrongdoing on their part would be in their minds less believable than a ghost story or demonic possession.
'
quote: '"See him, miss, first. THEN believe it!" I felt forthwith a new impatience to see him; it was the beginning of a curiosity that, for all the next hours, was to deepen almost to pain. Mrs. Grose was aware, I could judge, of what she had produced in me, and she followed it up with assurance. "You might as well believe it of the little lady. Bless her," she added the next moment--"LOOK at her!"

text:
'This dialogue is very funny, and if one reads (as one could) "The Turn of the Screw" as a viciously subtle farce about middle-class stupidity and neurotic sexual represssion, then this is one of the most blatant passages supporting that reading.

The governess is trapped by her upbringing within a fairy-tale morality of good and bad people, with the good epitomized by upper-class, pre-sexual, innocently beautiful children. Bad, however, is more complicated. As a sexual being, however, she is attracted to men with a naughty spirit, but is repulsed by the idea of naughtiness to the point of contamination and corruption (she also assumes that that is Mrs. Grose''s sexual preference).

What exactly is "bad" and what are the relationships between "naughtiness" and "evil," and between "clean naughtiness" vs. "corrupt naughtiness" are the questions at the center of her psychological confusion throughout the novella.
'
quote: '"I take what you said to me at noon as a declaration that YOU''VE never known him to be bad." She threw back her head; she had clearly, by this time, and very honestly, adopted an attitude. "Oh, never known him-- I don''t pretend THAT!" I was upset again. "Then you HAVE known him--?" "Yes indeed, miss, thank God!" On reflection I accepted this. "You mean that a boy who never is--?" "Is no boy for ME!" I held her tighter. "You like them with the spirit to be naughty?" Then, keeping pace with her answer, "So do I!" I eagerly brought out. "But not to the degree to contaminate--" "To contaminate?"--my big word left her at a loss. I explained it. "To corrupt." She stared, taking my meaning in; but it produced in her an odd laugh. "Are you afraid he''ll corrupt YOU?" She put the question with such a fine bold humor that, with a laugh, a little silly doubtless, to match her own, I gave way for the time to the apprehension of ridicule.

text:
'"He seems to like us young and pretty" is a general statement and something of a truism about most heterosexual men. As far as the governess knows at this point, the sexual universe of the novel includes only one man, the employer, and that is the "he" she is referring to. But the housekeeper''s equivocation opens up the field of "he"s to include both Miles (subcosnciously sexualized by the governess with her "naughty" comment) and a third man who remains nameless and featureless at this point.
'
quote: '"He seems to like us young and pretty!" "Oh, he DID," Mrs. Grose assented: "it was the way he liked everyone!" She had no sooner spoken indeed than she caught herself up. "I mean that''s HIS way--the master''s." I was struck. "But of whom did you speak first?" She looked blank, but she colored. "Why, of HIM." "Of the master?" "Of who else?" There was so obviously no one else that the next moment I had lost my impression of her having accidentally said more than she meant;

text:
'The "scruples" of the governess are in fact impeding any kind of meaningful communication between her and the housekeeper. The conversation here veers into the absurd just as she might expect to receive some useful information. James uses the nonsense of repressed speech as a strategy of delay and to emphasize the ambiguity of his story.
'
quote: 'I had a scruple, but I overcame it. "Was she careful--particular?" Mrs. Grose appeared to try to be conscientious. "About some things--yes." "But not about all?" Again she considered. "Well, miss--she''s gone. I won''t tell tales." "I quite understand your feeling," I hastened to reply;

text:
'Her indignation now is hyperbolic and her blind take on a child (or is it a young man?) she has just met is completely irrational.
'
quote: 'on the ground of my stupefaction, my general emotion: so monstrous was I then ready to pronounce it that such a child as had now been revealed to me should be under an interdict.

text:
'More flawed, on-the-spot character assessments.
'
quote: 'I felt, as he stood wistfully looking out for me before the door of the inn at which the coach had put him down, that I had seen him, on the instant, without and within, in the great glow of freshness, the same positive fragrance of purity, in which I had, from the first moment, seen his little sister.

text:
'Yes, but what kind of love?
'
quote: 'his indescribable little air of knowing nothing in the world but love.

text:
'The headmaster had attacked Miles'' reputation, his "good name." Again, in the fabulous mental world of feudal fantasy within the governess'' imagination, property and a good name go hand in hand with "good breeding," beauty, and desirability.
'
quote: 'to carry a bad name

text:
'It was. But so are many things in reality. Implicit in her comment is a denial that there is room in the world (or is it in her world?) for the grotesque. (Jane Austen''s Emma shares this peculiar notion--cf. the incident with the gypsies.)
'
quote: 'it was grotesque.

text:
'Overwhelmed by her preconceptions and her middle-class conditioning, the governess is rendered literally dumb. Her silence is aped by Mrs. Grose with some relief at not having to deal with the issue.
'
quote: 'What will you say, then?" she immediately added. "In answer to the letter?" I had made up my mind. "Nothing." "And to his uncle?" I was incisive. "Nothing." "And to the boy himself?" I was wonderful. "Nothing."

text:
'Though she fantasizes about upward mobility and being "carried away" by the master (or by Miles), the governess'' instinctive kinship ("like sisters") is with the housekeeper.
'
quote: '"Would you mind, miss, if I used the freedom--" "To kiss me? No!" I took the good creature in my arms and, after we had embraced like sisters, felt still more fortified and indignant.

text:
'In her solitary moment, the governess lingers on her almost masturbatory fantasies about her employer. Notice the language of sexual contact that she uses to characterize her fantasies about her professional duties.

(A similar dynamic between employee and employer occurs in the short story "Secretary" (1988) by Mary Gaitskill and its 2002 film adaptation.)
'
quote: 'It was a pleasure at these moments to feel myself tranquil and justified; doubtless, perhaps, also to reflect that by my discretion, my quiet good sense and general high propriety, I was giving pleasure-- if he ever thought of it!--to the person to whose pressure I had responded.

text:
'Thus begins the turning point that all the previous pages have been leading to. Notice the vague language: "what suddenly broke," "something," like "a beast."
'
quote: 'It may be, of course, above all, that what suddenly broke into this gives the previous time a charm of stillness-- that hush in which something gathers or crouches. The change was actually like the spring of a beast.

text:
'Her isolation is leading her to a fantasy of being in a story, and since she is not very sophisticated, her chosen story is a cheap romance. (In modern screenwriting terms, she wants to be in a romantic comedy and "meet cute.")
'
quote: 'One of the thoughts that, as I don''t in the least shrink now from noting, used to be with me in these wanderings was that it would be as charming as a charming story suddenly to meet someone.

text:
'With the benefit of hinsight, the older governess realizes that she was way out of her depth attempting to educate a budding "man of the world."
'
quote: 'I had undertaken, with my companion, to see it out, and I was under a charm, apparently, that could smooth away the extent and the far and difficult connections of such an effort. I was lifted aloft on a great wave of infatuation and pity. I found it simple, in my ignorance, my confusion, and perhaps my conceit, to assume that I could deal with a boy whose education for the world was all on the point of beginning.

text:
'In the governess'' fantasy, the children are actually royal and their world is like a fairy tale. This is explciitly linked with (sexual) innocence and an almost paranoid fear of "the world" and "the future," a place of bruises, corruption, and soiling.
'
quote: 'I used to speculate-- but even this with a dim disconnectedness--as to how the rough future (for all futures are rough!) would handle them and might bruise them. They had the bloom of health and happiness; and yet, as if I had been in charge of a pair of little grandees, of princes of the blood, for whom everything, to be right, would have to be enclosed and protected, the only form that, in my fancy, the afteryears could take for them was that of a romantic, a really royal extension of the garden and the park.

text:
'Notice the almost pathological need for approval. This is also what she wants most from her employer, and all her fantasy men tend to merge with him.
'
quote: 'would stand before me and smile and approve.

text:
'A wink at the traditional setting of the gothic horror story, where the real ruinous past, the modern present, and a fake replica of that past all merge.
'
quote: 'dating, in their gingerbread antiquity, from a romantic revival that was already a respectable past.

text:
'The first apparition. "He" in this context conflates the governess'' imaginary prince charming with her fantasies of the master.

The appearance on top of a tower can be read in a number of ways, all denoting superiority and distance. (The obvious--and nowadays trite--psychoanalytic reading of the tower as a phallus is part of a network of meanings that are coherent with her social and personal subjection.)
'
quote: 'What arrested me on the spot-- and with a shock much greater than any vision had allowed for-- was the sense that my imagination had, in a flash, turned real. He did stand there!--but high up, beyond the lawn and at the very top of the tower to which, on that first morning, little Flora had conducted me.

text: 'Notice the conflation of her "ideal man" from her book-infected dreams with her employer.'
quote: 'not the person I had precipitately supposed.

text:
'Even her fear (a supposedly spontaneous feeling) is mediated by what she thinks is expected of or permitted to her.

Her desire is only "allowed" (by society? by herself?) as long as the object is a fantastic dream-man.
'
quote: 'An unknown man in a lonely place is a permitted object of fear to a young woman privately bred; and the figure that faced me was--a few more seconds assured me--as little anyone else I knew as it was the image that had been in my mind. I had not seen it in Harley Street--I had not seen it anywhere.

text: 'This extremely specific description of a perceptive change served also a prescient sound-cue for much later film adaptations of the novella. Sound film was not developed until almost 30 years after "The Turn of the Screw," so what we would describe as a uniquely cinematic trope already occurs in the psychological novel.'
quote: 'It was as if, while I took in--what I did take in--all the rest of the scene had been stricken with death. I can hear again, as I write, the intense hush in which the sounds of evening dropped. The rooks stopped cawing in the golden sky, and the friendly hour lost, for the minute, all its voice.

text: 'James is again subverting the conventions of gothic apparitions (darkness, delirious mist).'
quote: 'I saw with a stranger sharpness. The gold was still in the sky, the clearness in the air, and the man who looked at me over the battlements was as definite as a picture in a frame.

text: 'A poetic summation of existential anxiety that, if taken out of the novella, could be inserted in a number of late 19th and 20th century narratives of alienation. Here it elevates the plot of a gothic ghost story into the much more inner horrors of the modern condition.'
quote: 'We were confronted across our distance quite long enough for me to ask myself with intensity who then he was and to feel, as an effect of my inability to say, a wonder that in a few instants more became intense.

text: 'She''s now channeling her spontaneous feelings through her duties as a governess, again avoiding the question of her initial surprise.'
quote: 'in there having been in the house--and for how long, above all?-- a person of whom I was in ignorance. It lasted while I just bridled a little with the sense that my office demanded that there should be no such ignorance and no such person.

text: 'Erect of course has a very literal meaning that connects the "visitant" with the imposing tower and the house itself--he is linked with the very fabric of the building in a way that threatens the governess. The secondary sexual implication might or might not be intended by James, but it makes for a intriguing reading given the revelations of erotic activity that ensue as the tale develops.'
quote: 'He was in one of the angles, the one away from the house, very erect, as it struck me, and with both hands on the ledge.

text: '(See previous note about "very erect.")'
quote: 'looking at me hard all the while,

text: '"Crenellation (or crenelation, also known as castellation) is the name for the distinctive pattern that frames the tops of the walls of many medieval castles, often called battlements. Crenellation most commonly takes the form of multiple, regular, rectangular spaces cut out of the top of the wall to allow defenders spaces to shoot arrows from and other spaces to hide behind full cover." '
quote: 'passed from one of the crenelations to the next.

text:
'Another instance of "lampshade hanging," and a very blatant one at that. The governess is very familiar with the conventions of the gothic novel in the same way Buffy the Vampire Slayer and her friends or the protagonists of the "Scream" films are familiar with previous horror cliches and conventions. This device allows the writers and filmmakers to address the cynicism of a jaded reader or viewer while still peddling a supernatural story.

"Udolpho" refers to the famous gothic novel "The Mysteries of Udolpho," written by Ann Radcliffe and published in 1794. This is the novel that is alluded to in Jane Austen''s "Northanger Abbey," another example (like James'' novella) of a gothic tale that revises the standard gothic scenarios.

The "unmentionable relative kept in unsuspected confinement" is a reference to another gothic cliche, most famously used by Charlotte Bronte in "Jane Eyre."
'
quote: 'Was there a "secret" at Bly--a mystery of Udolpho or an insane, an unmentionable relative kept in unsuspected confinement?

text: 'The governess is making the decision to withhold what she has seen from the housekeeper, a decision she later (as she''s writing the story) terms "odd." James continues to develop his subtle characterization of the governess as prey to her self-righteous neuroses--notice how she''s presenting her secrecy in the language of self-sacrifice and moral virtue (her "inward resolution").'
quote: 'I had not suspected in advance that her comfortable face would pull me up, and I somehow measured the importance of what I had seen by my thus finding myself hesitate to mention it. Scarce anything in the whole history seems to me so odd as this fact that my real beginning of fear was one, as I may say, with the instinct of sparing my companion. On the spot, accordingly, in the pleasant hall and with her eyes on me, I, for a reason that I couldn''t then have phrased, achieved an inward resolution--offered

text: '"Queer" simply meant "strange" at the time, though it was in the process of acquiring the current (and nowadays pretty much exclusive) meaning.'
quote: 'it was a queer affair enough.

text: '"Clear duties" is a very apt term for the kind of activity that someone like the governess allegedly prefers. This is contrasted with the amorphous mental activities and desires that threaten her sense of self (in this sentence, even taking over the time that should be devoted to these "clear duties").'
quote: 'clear duties--when

text:
'"Intimately" here continues the idea of the link between her fascination with "the visitor" and her own daydreams and erotic desires.

Notice also that her use of the term "visitor" or "visitant" subconsciously refers to her desire for her employer to "visit" Bly, something that he''s clearly reluctant to do. (It also denies what the rest of the story makes quite clear: she is the visitor there, and the apparitions are much more a part of Bly than she can ever be.)
'
quote: 'I could arrive at no account whatever of the visitor with whom I had been so inexplicably and yet, as it seemed to me, so intimately concerned.

text: 'This "liberty rather gross" continues her middle-class panic about speaking plainly, even to herself, and her neurotic euphemisms conflating transgressions (supernatural and natural), eroticism, and her own fantasies.'
quote: 'Of whatever it was that I knew, nothing was known around me. There was but one sane inference: someone had taken a liberty rather gross. That was what, repeatedly, I dipped into my room and locked the door to say to myself.

text: 'After making the most exaggerated kind of implication (the "liberty rather gross"), James mocks the governess by having her follow it up with an absurdly incongruous explanation: the menacing intruder must have merely been a harmless sightseer, trespassing purely in the interest of architectural tourism.'
quote: 'We had been, collectively, subject to an intrusion; some unscrupulous traveler, curious in old houses, had made his way in unobserved, enjoyed the prospect from the best point of view, and then stolen out as he came.

text: 'The governess is reassuring herself with the comforting naivete of "proper" 19th century sexual morality: an indiscretion was an inappropriate look, and a predatory man could be held bay by being told off for being "bold."'
quote: 'If he had given me such a bold hard stare, that was but a part of his indiscretion.

text: 'This figurative "gray prose" stands in contrast to the "fantastic literature" that she has already mentioned as coloring her views of her employer, Bly, and her own possibilities.'
quote: 'the probable gray prose of my office. There was to be no gray prose, it appeared, and no long grind; so how could work not be charming that presented itself as daily beauty? It was all the romance of the nursery and the poetry of the schoolroom. I don''t mean by this, of course, that we studied only fiction and verse; I mean I can express no otherwise the sort of interest my companions inspired.

text: 'A further elaboration on the governess'' delusion that she can judge character just by "looking." (Her eyesight or fancifulness haven''t been questioned by her in regards to the apparition on the castle--in fact at this point she has convinced herself of her own "trespassing sightseer with somewhat roving eyes" theory).'
quote: 'There was one direction, assuredly, in which these discoveries stopped: deep obscurity continued to cover the region of the boy''s conduct at school. It had been promptly given me, I have noted, to face that mystery without a pang. Perhaps even it would be nearer the truth to say that--without a word--he himself had cleared it up. He had made the whole charge absurd. My conclusion bloomed there with the real rose flush of his innocence: he was only too fine and fair for the little horrid, unclean school world, and he had paid a price for it. I reflected acutely that the sense of such differences, such superiorities of quality, always, on the part of the majority--which could include even stupid, sordid headmasters-- turn infallibly to the vindictive.

text:
'"Gentleness" is derived from ancient ideas about qualities that a "gentleman" or "member of the gentry" possess. This vestigial etymology is behind the instinctive awe that these landed children cause in the governess, an educated member of the serving classes. In a fundamental way, they are also "quite unpunishable" by her, though she''s been temporarily given the power to do so by their uncle.

A "muff" is a 19th century word meaning "a foolish, stupid, feeble, or incompetent person; spec. one who is clumsy or awkward in some sport or manual skill" (OED).'
quote: 'Both the children had a gentleness (it was their only fault, and it never made Miles a muff) that kept them--how shall I express it?--almost impersonal and certainly quite unpunishable.

text: 'Her obsession with cleanliness vs. corruption continues--in the case of the boy, the "unclean" world is the school, and by extension, the socializing of the young man after his time in the nursery (the passage from child to man).'
quote: 'the little horrid, unclean school world,

text: 'According to a commonplace story, angels were so ethereal and good that they didn''t have a butt to spank.'
quote: 'They were like the cherubs of the anecdote, who had-- morally, at any rate--nothing to whack!

text: 'The irony is that according to ancient feudal notion Miles is the one with a history: that''s what is meant by heritage and inheritance, embodied in the huge house at Bly. The governess, as a servant, would have been seen as historically irrelevant by those holding on to aristocratic notions. (Only a Socialist, or later a Communist, would have considered the working and serving classes as having a "history" worth telling.)'
quote: 'as if he had had, as it were, no history.
